answers.author: Pamela Muse
answers.text:
Roger – I hope the following is helpful:
Ohio Law - “…If the court determines that the offender is indigent and unable to pay the financial sanction or court costs, the court shall consider imposing and may impose a term of community service…”
http://codes.ohio.gov/orc/2929.28 
Florida – MISDEMEANOR DIVERSION PROGRAM CONTRACT  http://sa14.fl.gov/Diversion/Documents/Contract.pdf 
WA State Courts
See:    CrRLJ 07.0600  Order Allowing Community Service Work in Lieu of Payment, Incarceration, Criminal, Infraction (ORACS)
http://www.courts.wa.gov/forms/?fa=forms.contribute&formID=27 
Article – Proposed ordinance could make juvenile criminal misdemeanors a city ordinance violation
“…Offenders who cannot afford the fees may elect to perform community service in lieu of payment…”
http://www.beardstownnewspapers.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5273%3Aproposed-ordinance-could-make-juvenile-criminal-misdemeanors-a-city-ordinance-violation&Itemid=183 
Happy Holiday!
Pam
Pamela Muse

author: Roger Kolman
text: We are seeking a model to emulate of an effective community service program for misdemeanor and traffic offenders to contribute "sweat equity" to their community in lieu of cash payment for some or all of their fines. Does such a model exist with adequate policies and procedures that protect the offender as well as the city/court?
title: Community Service
